§L Though allowed to remain in Italy when all other Ponipeians were driven out, Cicero was not happy3 he had broken with his brother Quintus, and Terentia (he alleged) had mismanaged his finan- cial affairs in his absence ; while Dolabella, his son- in-law, was so notoriously unfaithful to Tullia as to make a divorce inevitable.

§a He was consoled, however, by a reassuring letter from Caesar in Egypt, who permitted him to retain his lictors and the title of inzperator3 on Caesar's return Cicero met him and was cordially received, and being given leave to live wherever he liked, he chose Tusculum, so as to be near Rome.
